column4:
Rrrrring rrrrring. An annoying ringing jolts you from a pleasant daydream. Who could be calling? You're in your office, sitting at your run-down old desk ... being a private investigator just doesn't seem pay much these days. At least, not since the Veil ripped open 4 years ago and magic returned to the world. Who wants to spend money on a PI when you can find a locator spell on the internet for free? Maybe it's time to close up shop and... Oh yeah, the phone is still ringing - maybe you should answer it? 

You answer the phone. The caller is a well-known professor of demonology at the city college. Cool, you've seen her on TV. Apparently her graduate assistant has been missing for several days, and all of her demonic contacts are 'suspiciously tight-lipped' on the subject. She offers to pay your weekly rate of 1000 gold to have you track down her wayward student. Jackpot! The last place she saw the guy was at a bar just a couple blocks away from your office. That's probably a good place to start.
You're in the hallway outside your office. When you walk over a particular spot on the carpet, you feel a bump. Is there something under there?

Still in the hallway. How have you never noticed before how long this hallway is? It feels like you've been in here forever, and you can see that you've only covered about two-thirds of the distance. Uh oh, there's your landlord Fyodor! He threatened to cancel your lease if you're late on your rent again... And oh no, he saw you! Maybe you can distract him - ask him some questions, see if you can get him talking.
There's the door to the street! Small problem though. There's an eight-foot tall wyvern blocking the door and he looks grumpy. He looks your way and snarls. I guess it's time for a fight!

A line of storefronts stretches along this street. Years ago they may have sold ladies' hats, hardware, or any number of mundane objects, but recently they've mostly turned over to alchemical supplies, crystals, enchanted amulets, and other magical accessories. A few groups of young women weave in and out of the shops, giggling conspiratorially among themselves over their latest purchases.

The intersection of Birch Street and a street the locals call 'Red Alley'. Off to the east you see nice, though modest, houses. To the south is Red Alley, a narrow path between buildings where they keep the dumpsters. Who knows what might be lurking there?

The smell of old, hot garbage permeates the air in Red Alley. Some of these dumpsters haven't been emptied in a while - apparently someone is behind on their payments to the garbage trolls. The grease smell of fried food mingles nauseatingly with the garbage odor. You must be behind that new fast food place, Lord of the Fries.

As you wander this street of once-stately apartment homes, you're assaulted by the sour odor of crushed mulberries underfoot.  The cement squares of the sidewalk bend and buckle as roots of gnarled old trees shatter their way through to the sunlight. Aside from the belligerent  squawking of birds overhead, it's eerily quiet.

Sandwiched between blocks of neglect, Birch St. stands proudly out of place. Its modest family homes and townhouses project an  order and cleanliness that is practically suburban, from its stately shade trees to the odd ceramic lawn ornament. You find the sidewalk clean and even, only having to dodge the odd lawn sprinkler.  A small wind blows from the east.

Throngs of people moving in every direction choke the narrow walkway down Main St. Street vendors, their stands taking up even more precious space, hawk everything from knockoff designer bags to love potions. A faint smell of smoke in the air signals a kebab stand in the vicinity. You remind your growling stomach that you have more pressing matters at hand.

Large old homes dominate this stretch. Most were sold far below market price in the panic felt by the city's elites after the emergence of magic. It's clear that students from the nearby university have taken over the vacated neighborhood, at least if the couches on the porches and vague aroma of marijuana and incense are any indication. Crushed beer cans, textbooks, and the odd spell tome complete the picture.  The pages of a discarded Harry Potter book flap in the breeze.

You find yourself drifting through a cavernous room filled with mist. What happened? Where are you? Wasn't there something important you needed to do? As you drift around the room your cares fall away and you feel... at peace. Death isn't so bad after all.
